fight.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to take part in a war or battle
fight.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Neither country is capable of fighting a long war.
Later the Indians fought the Anglo settlers.
the families of those who fought in the war
rebel forces fighting against the Russians
They fought for control of the islands.
fight.translation[0].definitions[0].note: Fight is a reciprocal verb This type of verb is used when saying that two or more people or groups do something that involves both or all of them It does not need to have an object  In this sentence, fight is intransitive and does not have an object
The Republicans and the Nationalists fought
In these sentences, fight is transitive
The Republicans and the Nationalists fought each other
fight.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: if someone fights another person, or if two people fight, they hit and kick the other person in order to hurt them
fight.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: She fought him desperately, kicking and biting.
Two guys were fighting with each other in the street.
They were fighting over a girl.
fight.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to try hard to do or get something
fight.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: The men were fighting for higher wages.
Stockley is fighting for his life (=trying to stay alive), with serious head injuries.
She fought her way back into the first team.
The president was fighting to survive.
fight.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to try very hard to prevent something or to get rid of something unpleasant that already exists
fight.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: We will fight terrorism, wherever it exists.
People are fighting against repression and injustice.
fight.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to take part in an election or compete strongly for something, especially a job or political position
fight.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: The prime minister decided to fight an early general election.
He had to fight several other applicants for the job.
Both men were used to fighting for power.
fight.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: I heard her fighting with the boss.
They’re fighting about who should do the dishes.
fight.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: to take part in a boxing match
fight.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: Ali fought Foreman for the heavyweight title.
fight.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: to try very hard not to have or show a feeling
fight.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: She was clearly fighting with her emotions.
fight.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: to try to get something or prevent something in a court of law
fight.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: The insurance company are fighting the claims in court.
fight.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a situation in which two people or groups hit, push etc each other
fight.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Her son was always getting into fights at school.
They ended up having a fight with each other.
A fight broke out between the fans.
fight.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: the process of trying to achieve something or prevent something
fight.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: You’ll have a fight on your hands (=it will be difficult) to convince the committee.
the fight for justice and democracy
The little girl lost her fight for life (=fight to stay alive) last night.
the fight to get financial aid
fight.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: They’ve had a fight with the neighbours.
fight.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: Are you going to watch the big fight tonight?
fight.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: energy or the desire to keep fighting for something you want
fight.translation[1].definitions[5].exam: There’s plenty of fight left in your grandmother.
fight.translation[1].note_box[0].section: I didn’t want to have a fight with him.
The two men got into a fight over a girl.
They started a fight in the crowded bar.
The guy tried to pick a fight with Jack.
stop a fight/break up a fight
The police were called in to break up a fight outside a nightclub.
He always won every fight he was in at school.
The kids went round in gangs, all spoiling for a fight.
A fight broke out and one man was struck on the head.
The fight took place outside a nightclub.
They ended up having a big fight in the pub.
It was a fair fight, just two on two.
There was a fierce fight with rebel forces and several soldiers were killed.
There were reports of street fights every night in the local newspaper.
A fist fight broke out after the match.
There have been several arrests, following knife fights between drunken fans.
fight.translation[1].note_box[1].section: when people hit or attack each other
fight
a situation in which people hit or attack each other because of an argument, or as a sport
He had a fight with an older boy.
the famous fight between Muhammad Ali and George Foreman
battle
a fight between opposing armies or groups of people
The English king was killed at the Battle of Hastings.
a battle between two rival gangs
scuffle
a short fight that is not very violent
There was a short scuffle with the police, but no arrests were made.
punch-up
a fight in which people hit each other because of an argument
The game turned into a punch-up.
brawl
a noisy fight between a group of people
He was hurt in a drunken brawl.
altercation
a short noisy argument or fight, especially one that is not serious
There was a brief altercation and someone called the police.
riot
a fight involving a large number of people, especially people who are protesting about something
The book provoked riots all over Europe.
when people try to achieve something
fight
the process in which people try to stop something bad from happening or to improve a situation
Schools have an important part to play in the fight against drugs.
women’s fight for equality
battle
a fight to change a situation or deal with a problem in society
The battle against racial discrimination is not over.
campaign
a planned series of actions intended to achieve something
Motoring organizations started a campaign for safer roads.
struggle
a long, hard fight for freedom, independence, equal rights etc
Nkrumah led the people in their struggle for independence.
crusade
someone’s fight against something they think is morally wrong
She intends to continue her crusade against sex and violence on TV.
